fields.caption: Teresa Elam, a distant relative of President James K. Polk’s, at the site where he and his wife are buried on the grounds of the Capitol in Nashville. She said a proposal to disinter their remains would amount to desecration of their graves.
Tom Price is the curator of the James K. Polk Home and Museum in Columbia, Tenn. Moving the remains of Polk and his wife there would honor the former president’s wishes, he said.
Polk’s second burial site in Nashville. The columns and cenotaph were eventually moved to the Capitol grounds in the 1890s, and remain there today.
